intro: Quiina pubescens, commonly known as the hairy quiina, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly found in regions of Peru and Ecuador. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf structures and often edible parts. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves, which help it retain moisture in arid environments. It produces small, greenish flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, and it is often used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits. Its botanical features make it well adapted to its native habitat, contributing to its ecological significance in the region.
